item.title: The Role of Periodicity in Global Tax Administration: Theory, Commonalities, and Operational Impact
item.description:
Tax administration systems worldwide rely on foundational principles to ensure efficiency, compliance, and fairness. Among these principles, periodicity -the systematic division of tax obligations into discrete time intervals- serves as a cornerstone for both governments and taxpayers. This article explores the theoretical underpinnings of tax periodicity, identifies common practices across jurisdictions, analyzes its operational impact on accountants, and proposes best practices for optimizing its implementation.

1. Theoretical Foundations of Tax Periodicity

Defining Periodicity in Tax Contexts

The periodicity assumption, rooted in accounting theory, posits that financial activities must be segmented into standardized time frames to facilitate reporting, analysis, and decision-making123. In tax administration, this translates to governments mandating that taxpayers calculate and remit liabilities over predefined intervals, such as monthly, quarterly, or annually. These periods align with fiscal years, corporate accounting cycles, or legislative requirements, creating a structured framework for revenue collection45.
